title: ‘Miraculously preserved’ ancient Egyptian king in Cairo? No, photo of female mummy in Roman museum
subtitle: Does a photo show the body of an ancient Egyptian pharaoh called “
author: africacheck.org
vclaim:
Does a photo show the body of an ancient Egyptian pharaoh called “

despite being “inside the sea for more than 3000 years”?

No, but that’s the claim in

in Nigeria in May 2019.

Miraculous preservation of pharaoh's dead body. This is the dead body of... the Egyptian Pharaoh (king) Fir'auna. Its age is approximately 3000 years... This body is now displayed in... the Egyptian Museum in Cairo

This dead body is amazingly preserved without any mummification; no inside organs have been removed... Phoroah's body was inside the sea for more than 3000years. Fish in the sea could have easily eaten the flesh, but they didn't.”

The post goes on to say that

Fir'auna (it also calls him “

Fia'aun” and “Firaun”) was a “cruel king” who “denied the existence of God Almighty”, so “Allah made him drown in the Red Sea and Allah preserved his body over 3000 years without any mummification”.

brings up a similar photo of the body, on the website

. The photo shows a mummy of a woman – not a king – dated at

1070 to 945 BCE and found in

, an ancient Egyptian city on the Nile river some 800 kilometres south of the Mediterranean sea.

The mummy is held at the

So, no. The photo doesn’t show a king – it’s

. The body has been

– not “miraculously preserved”. It was found on dry land, and is in a museum in Rome, not the Egyptian capital of Cairo.
